content:
The letter you've provided does a good job of outlining your concerns with the landlord's conduct regarding the speed and notice given for repairs. It also effectively communicates the impact that this is having on your mental and physical well-being as a disabled person with autism. It also highlights how the landlord's behavior is impacting your daily life and your ability to make plans and commitments. It also mentions that you have been afraid of bringing up these concerns as you don't want to jeopardize your living situation.

It also mentions that you have asked the landlord many times for proper notice and communication, and that it was only recently that he began providing proper notice, but it is not consistent. It also mentions that the landlord's communication is often poor, and that he will not update you if he is severely late or not coming at all until many hours after the initial time he said he would arrive.

It also brings up specific examples of the repairs that have taken place, and how long they have taken, and how it has affected the use of certain parts of the house, and how it has been done without consulting you. It also mentions that the garage issue which took more than a year for him to resolve left you without the use of an integral part of the house for a year directly after a rent increase.

Overall, the letter is a clear and concise way to express your concerns and it effectively communicates the impact that the landlord's conduct is having on your well-being. It also mentions the legal requirements regarding notice and communication and it highlights the negative impact of the landlord's behavior in a clear and factual manner.
